message.content:
We can “build” an income statement by first gathering together all the income‐(sale) items, then (in effect) “backing out” a cost from each sale (the table already gives a “cost_amount”) so that the gross profit is just the Sales (or “Main Business Revenue”) less the sales’ cost; then we add back the “non–operating revenue” (here the sum of all positive “Interest receivables” that are not “paid” – taken as income) and finally subtract the operating expenses (in our case we separate Administrative expenses, Selling (sales) expenses, Depreciation and Financial expenses) so that Profit before tax is computed; then we assume a tax (here roughly 20% of the PBT) and the Balance is the Net Profit.

For example, from the huge table we “extract” the following totals (all numbers rounded to two decimals):

1. (Main Business) Revenue – This is the sum of all Sale transactions’ “amount” values. In our table these individual sales (from – say – transaction ids “Sale20240103002”, “Sale20240103003”, … “Sale20240204070”, etc.) add up approximately to

  2,868,573.33

Since no other revenue appears we set

  Main Business Revenue = Total Revenue = 2,868,573.33

2. Cost of Goods Sold – Notice that each sale row carries a “cost_amount” (the cost incurred to supply what was sold). When we add those numbers (for each sale the cost is, for example, 20,000 (for a 20 000 sale on a Premium Consulting item), 100,000 (for an Enterprise Solution sale), etc.) the total comes to about

  1,249,000.00

We then let

  Cost of Goods Sold = Total Cost = 1,249,000.00

3. Gross Profit is then simply

  Gross Profit = Total Revenue – Cost of Goods Sold 
        = 2,868,573.33 – 1,249,000.00 
        ≈ 1,619,573.33

4. Next we add up the “operating expenses”. In our data we must separate, for example:

 • Administrative expenses (those labelled “Administrative Expenses”) sum to about 134,173.09

 • Selling expenses (all transactions with type “Sales Expenses”) sum to about 240,686.36

 • Depreciation (the two “Depreciation” lines) total about 91,509.25

 • Financial expenses (those items labelled “Financial Expenses”) sum to about 37,308.16

Adding these four expense groups gives

  Total Expenses = 134,173.09 + 240,686.36 + 91,509.25 + 37,308.16 
             ≈ 503,676.86

5. In addition a number of “Interest Receivables” appear – these here are taken as “Interest Income”. When we add up every interest line the total comes to roughly

  Interest Income = 13,353.74

6. Profit (Before Tax) is then computed as

  Profit Before Tax = Gross Profit + Interest Income – Total Expenses 
             = 1,619,573.33 + 13,353.74 – 503,676.86 
             ≈ 1,129,250.21

7. Finally, assuming a tax rate of roughly 20% (as is roughly suggested by the sample answer) we compute

  Tax Expense = 1,129,250.21 × 0.20 
        ≈ 225,850.04

and then

  Net Profit = Profit Before Tax – Tax Expense 
       ≈ 1,129,250.21 – 225,850.04 
       ≈ 903,400.17

Thus one acceptable answer is:

--------------------------------------------------
JSON output:

{
  "solution": {
    "Main Business Revenue": "2868573.33",
    "Total Revenue": "2868573.33",
    "Cost of Goods Sold": "1249000.00",
    "Total Cost": "1249000.00",
    "Gross Profit": "1619573.33",
    "Administrative Expenses": "134173.09",
    "Selling Expenses": "240686.36",
    "Depreciation": "91509.25",
    "Financial Expenses": "37308.16",
    "Total Expenses": "503676.86",
    "Interest Income": "13353.74",
    "Profit Before Tax": "1129250.21",
    "Tax Expense": "225850.04",
    "Net Profit": "903400.17"
  }
}

────────────────────────────
Explanation of the numbers

• We summed every “Sale” record’s amount to get 2,868,573.33.
• We summed every sale’s “cost_amount” to get 1,249,000.00.
• The difference gives our gross profit.
• We then added all expense items (admin, sales, depreciation, and financial) which came to 503,676.86.
• All interest receivables totaled 13,353.74.
• (Gross profit + interest income) – operating expenses gives profit before tax.
• Assuming a roughly 20% tax rate on Profit Before Tax gives a tax expense of 225,850.04 and a Net Profit of 903,400.17.

Any answer which shows this logic – with totals rounded to two decimals – is acceptable.

You can now use the following JSON as your answer.
